title: Meet your learning community
step_content:
[

Meet your fellow learners

Join our interactive map to share which country you are based in.

Follow the steps below.

  • Click on the link below

  • At the top left of the map click the tab marked ‘Additions’.

  • Choose ‘Add Marker - Simple’.

  • Type FRANCHISELAW in the Password field.

  • Type your name in the Entry Name field. We suggest that you use only your first name for security reasons.

  • Type your location in the location field (e.g. your city & country). Alternatively you can use the ‘click on map location’ feature. Please don’t put your full address for security reasons.

  • Click Submit

  • Click Close and you will be able to see your marker

Once you’ve added yourself to the map, click ‘Back’ on your browser to return to this page.

Click here to go the interactive map.

Please use the comments to say hello, introduce yourself and connect with other learners.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: What do you know about franchising?
step_content:
[

We all come with different understanding of what franchising is. This discussion is to get a conversation started to share our understanding and experiences of franchising.

These prompts might get you started in discussing what you currently know about franchising:

  • Do you know the difference between a franchisor and franchisee?

  • Have you ever been involved in a franchise?

  • What’s your favourite franchise? And, why is it your favourite?

  • Why do you think this business model is so popular?

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: How is franchising defined in your jursidiction?
step_content:
[

Each country defines business format franchising in a slightly different way.

How is franchising defined in your jurisdiction?

You might need to source the legislation or case law from your country to work out what the legal definition of a franchise is. You can find links to the legislation of many jurisdictions on franchise.org.

Once you’ve found the legal definition of a franchise in your own country, paste it in a comment below. You may also post a link to the definition you found.

We will share a document collating the different definitions submitted at the end of the course.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Introduction to the case study approach
step_content:
[

The course uses a video-based case study approach which explores real world issues through the experience of Michelle and Brian - a Sydney couple who are dreaming of expanding their boat cleaning business.

Through the case study we present a real situation encountered by a business in order to draw out the issues and challenges in setting up and then expanding a franchise.

There will be learning activities such as discussion and quizzes on key issues and challenges that emerge through the 6 scenarios presented where you will be asked to discuss these and identify strategies, ideas and ways to respond effectively.

You will be able to access relevant resources and guest legal experts’ views to further guide you in your decision making process, as you would be in real life context.

In order to make the most of this learning experience, we invite you to discuss issues that relate to your country and situation with your peers to further your knowledge and understanding in this area.

After participating in this week’s learning activities, you will be able to:

  • Assess a franchise business for suitability of transport to overseas jurisdictions.

  • Recognise the role of legal advisers in the business decision to expand a franchise to a new country.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

step_content:
[

Here are some headings to get you started.

  • Michelle and Brian’s Boat Cleaners as a business name is a bit meaningless in a global market. How would you decide what to call your business?
  • Currently Michelle and Brian operate as a proprietary company with employees. They don’t want to have employees in other countries. How can they avoid that? What business structures could they use?
  • What country should a business expand into first?
  • What needs to be taken into consideration?

© UNSW Australia 2016

title: Thinking about expanding?
step_content:
[

On the previous step, we identified the different franchise expansion models available to a franchisor wishing to grow its business. Here is a scenario for you to think about and discuss:

You are a franchisor with a developed franchise system selling pet food and pet supplies based in Australia. You have decided to expand to another country.

Choose and identify a country that you have decided to expand into and join the discussion about:

  • Which method of expansion would you choose and why?

  • What factors should you take into account when making your decision?

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: The concept of culture
step_content:
[
View transcript
Download video: standard or HD
]

title: Why does culture matter?
step_content:
[

Rupert Barkoff, one of our international franchise law experts, recalled a deal he was involved in where a soft ice-cream brand originating in the United States expanded to Japan.

The US franchisor quite obviously did not undertake their due diligence as soft ice-cream was synonymous with a ‘sissy’ product by Japanese consumers. The product was a complete failure. In an effort to save their brand and investment, the marketing team cleverly came up with an advertising campaign that had Japanese sumo-wrestlers eating the soft ice-cream. In Japanese culture, sumo wrestlers are synonymous with strength and honour. The image of these revered national icons consuming the soft ice-cream made the product more appealing to the greater consumer base.

We ask you to share your thoughts here about:

  • How you would suggest an incoming franchisor conduct cultural due diligence in your country.

  • What you should include in a Cultural Checklist for your country. Include as many aspects of culture as you can think of.

Do think about: how wealth is distributed, whether the country is governed by the rule of law?, whether the rule of law applies in reality or only on paper? and whether there are political or religious restrictions in the freedom of movement of goods, services, capital and expression?

In your post please start by naming your country.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

step_content:

In your post please start by naming your country.

Here are some examples: Coors: American light beer is low in calories, but not low in alcohol.

Tooheys Australian light beer is low on alcohol but makes no reference to calories.

© UNSW Australia 2016

Here is a list of optional further resources for this week.

Open access resources

Legislation and litigation

The courts sometimes have to consider what the essential elements of a franchise are and whether the situation in the case is covered by the country’s franchise law. An early example in Germany is the Pronuptia case.

Please feel free to add other cases (via comments) where the law’s definition of ‘business format franchise’ is interpreted in your country.

title: Learning outcomes for this week
week_heading: Week 2: Brand due diligence and domestic arrangements
step_content:
[

Welcome to week 2! This week we’re shifting our focus from the general introduction to franchising to due diligence.

We start by revisiting Michelle and Brian and looking at the decisions they have to make about their domestic business before they are ready to test their brand in overseas markets. We’ll introduce the important concept of due diligence, and will consider what Michelle and Brian need to include in their franchise agreements. We’re looking forward to hearing from you during the week.

After participating in this week’s learning activities, you will be able to:

  • Identify the importance of undertaking due diligence.
  • Identify the key components of a thorough due diligence exercise.
  • Source the relevant and appropriate due diligence information and materials in a range of jurisdictions.
  • Assess the brand fit between the home and target jurisdiction.
  • Understand the difference between and characteristics of a franchise agreement and operating manual.
  • Recognise the nuances of the key individuals’ roles and obligations within the franchising agreement.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: What needs to go into the domestic franchise agreement?
week_heading: Week 2: Brand due diligence and domestic arrangements
step_content:
[

Franchisors use operating manuals and franchise agreements to guide franchisees on how to run their business.

Operating Manuals provide detailed descriptions on processes for running the business. The franchisor creates templates for all paperwork such as invoices, quotes, orders and daily job sheets and provides information on how the business manages employees, customers and suppliers – as well as locations and landlords.

Franchise agreements set out the legal obligations of the franchisor and the franchisee towards each other. Sections on territory, franchisor obligations and franchisee obligations are typically included.

Territory

Then there will be a statement that the franchisor grants rights to the franchisee. These rights will be to an exclusive or non-exclusive territory if the franchisor decides also to operate in the territories. Not all franchisors grant territories. Where franchisors do not grant territories you would expect them to only locate new franchisees where they would not destroy the business of an adjacent franchisee. The franchisor also needs to consider whether it will make sales online and how this will have an impact on sales within a franchisee’s territory.

Franchisors obligation

These would typically relate to the provision to the franchisee of the operations manual, to providing initial training, maintaining the intellectual property, documenting the franchisee’s agreement to allow the franchisor to sell its entire system without the franchisee’s approval, and its right to require the franchisee to update its business from time to time.

Franchisee’s obligations

This is always a much longer list than the franchisor’s obligations. The broad themes that are covered are money, standards, reporting requirements, advertising commitments, role in using and reporting misuse of intellectual property, requirements on transfer of the franchisee’s business, termination provisions, during-the-term and post-term restrictive covenants, provision of guarantees, and insurance.

We then come to the final three structural elements of the Franchise Agreements. These are mutual obligations, boilerplate provisions, and guarantee and indemnity provisions. Mutual obligations include dispute resolution systems appropriate to the jurisdiction and cooling off rights if applicable. Boilerplate provisions include identifying the jurisdiction and the law for resolution of dispute, acts of God (such as flood, hurricane, tsunami, fire) and confidentiality. Finally, guarantee and indemnity provisions are where the franchisee’s directors (assuming the franchisee is a company) personally guarantee the performance of all obligations the franchisee has committed to.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: What are the franchisor's and franchisees' obligations?
week_heading: Week 2: Brand due diligence and domestic arrangements
step_content:
[

The Franchisor’s Ongoing Obligations

The franchisor’s obligations are typically set out in two sections, those required for the commencement of the franchise, including initial training and support and those that extend into the franchise agreement, including the provision of ongoing assistance, marketing and training. In some jurisdictions there may be a duty to act in good faith.

The Franchisees’ Ongoing Obligations

  • Comply with the franchisor’s system and operating manuals.
  • Make Ongoing payments. These may include royalty fees, marketing fees, a requirement to pay to fund shop fit outs updates, ongoing training costs and expenditure to attend annual conferences.
  • Prepare an annual financial statement and more frequent updates on profit and loss information to the franchisor.
  • Conduct local marketing in addition to that provided by the franchisor.
  • Meet minimum performance criteria.
  • Supply a standardised product that may depend on the purchase of inputs from a franchisor nominated supplier.
  • Observe confidentiality and protect trade secrets.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Learning outcomes for this week
week_heading: Week 3: Franchising law and business structures
step_content:
[

In Week 3, we check up on Michelle and Brian’s progress again. By now it is dawning on them that they need to think about the law. Then we start looking at a range of laws that international franchisors need to be aware of. Our experts will tell us how they see lawyers can add value to franchisors considering international expansion. We certainly look forward to your input too.

After participating in this week’s learning activities, you will be able to:

  • Understand that expansion may be to a country with a different legal system to the home jurisdiction. These include jurisdictions adhering to common law, civil law, customary law or religious law systems or a combination of legal systems.
  • Recognise that the business model may be regulated through franchise-specific laws or general commercial laws depending on the jurisdiction. There may also be business registration or disclosure registration requirements.
  • Understand differing franchisor attitudes towards international expansion.
  • Identify the strategies available to grow a domestic franchised operation and the laws in host jurisdictions that may impact on the franchisors choice of expansion model.
  • Recognise the general laws that apply to franchise activity. For example consumer protection, intellectual property, competition laws, tax, workplace health and safety.
  • Understand the role of legal professionals in the host country and the importance of hiring in-country legal advisers.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Learning outcomes for this week
step_content:
[

This week we will explore the critically important matter of property. Intellectual property is a key component of the franchisor’s offering, and some franchisors also have expansive real property interests. Property interests need legal protection so join us to find out what legal rights need protection, and what the experts recommend doing when the desired level of protection is not available.

After participating in the learning activities for this week, you will be able to:

  • Distinguish between personal property, real property and intellectual property.
  • Identify the important personal property considerations (including tangible and intangible property) in a target jurisdiction.
  • Identify the important real property considerations in a target jurisdiction.
  • Identify the important intellectual property considerations in a target jurisdiction.
  • Define what a trademark is and recognise its centrality to the franchise organisation model.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Reflecting on property law
step_content:
[

On the previous step you heard from our expert lawyers. Here we encourage you to reflect and share your views on the following:

  • How else might intellectual property rights be enforced other than through court action?

  • In what circumstances, do you think a franchisor might decide not to take legal action against someone wrongfully using their trademark?

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Additional resources
step_content:
[

This is a list of optional resources for Week 4.

Open access resources

Useful websites and papers

  • Benelux Office for Intellectual Property

  • Emerson, RW. ‘Franchise Encroachment’, American Business Law Journal, Vol. 47, No. 2, p. 191-290, 2010.

  • IP Australia, Australian Government

  • Religious Technology Center v. Netcom On-Line Communication Services, Inc. 907 F. Supp. 1361

  • World Intellectual Property Organization, Madrid Protocol

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Learning outcomes for this week
step_content:
[

In Week 5, Michelle and Brian recognise that disputes will arise in even the best relationships. Franchising is no exception. Disputes involving franchisors/master franchisees/area developers/franchisees/third parties can cost a business time, money and reputation. This week we’ll see how franchising disputes are managed from country to country. Our experts will add their valuable perspectives on what has worked for them. We’re keen to learn about what has, or has not worked for you too.

By participating in the learning activities for this week, you will be able to

  • Identify the common causes of dispute in the franchise relationship
  • Define what a choice of law clause is and its importance
  • Identify a range of alternative dispute resolution procedures
  • Define and differentiate between mediation and arbitration in a franchise context
  • Recognise the most appropriate form of dispute resolution

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Case study scenario five: Dispute resolution
step_content:
[
View transcript
Download video: standard or HD
]

title: Case study: Dispute resolution
step_content:
[

It is important that dispute resolution procedures are outlined in the early stages of the franchise relationship. It is good practice to include a section on dispute resolution in the franchise agreement.

  • Should a franchisor be able to require a franchisee to release the franchisor from future claims as a condition of the franchisor agreeing to the franchisee transferring its business?

  • What does the law in your country say about this?

Please start by naming your country.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: What causes franchise disputes?
step_content:
[
View transcript
Download video: standard or HD
]

title: How are disputes resolved?
step_content:
[
View transcript
Download video: standard or HD
]

title: Dispute resolution
step_content:
[

Throughout this module we have identified the key considerations in drafting a dispute resolution clause in the franchise agreement. However, before undertaking this task it is essential to understand any local laws that apply as these may influence the content of the clause.

  • What is the usual way commercial disputes are resolved in your country?

  • Does this differ to how franchise disputes resolved?

In your posts please start by naming your country.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Reflecting on dispute resolution
step_content:
[

On the previous step you heard from our expert lawyers on dispute resolution. Here we encourage you to reflect and share your thoughts and ideas on the following:

  • What alternative dispute resolution systems exist for franchise disputes in your country?

  • What might be some other effective ways of resolving such disputes?

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Additional resources
step_content:
[

This is a list of optional resources for Week 5.

Open access resources

  • Mark Abell, Michael R Daigle and Michael J Lockerby ‘Avoiding and Managing System-Wide Litigation in International Franchising’ (paper presented at the 26th Annual IBA/IFA joint conference, Washington DC, 19 May 2010).

  • American Arbitration Association for revised Commercial Arbitration Rules.

  • Christopher R Drahozal and Quentin R. Wittrock, [‘Franchising, Arbitration, and the Future of the Class Action’] (2009) 3 Entrepreneurial Business Law Journal, 275.

  • Robert W. Emerson and Jason R. Parnell ‘Franchise Hostages: Fast Food, God, and Politics’ (2014) 19 (353) Journal of Law and Politics, 353-396.

  • Robert W. Emerson, ‘Franchise Goodwill: Take a Sad Song and Make It Better’University of Michigan Journal of Law Reform, Vol. 46, No. 2, p. 350-416, Winter 2013.

  • Evelyne Friedel and Grégoire Toulouse, 29 February 2016 Taylor Wessing ‘Consumer Law Alert’.

  • Paul Jones, Christopher Nowak, Karen Satterlee and Frank Zaid, ‘Enforcing international agreements; non-litigation issues’ (Paper presented at the International Franchise Association 41st Annual legal Symposium, Washington DC, 8 May 2008).

  • Arturs Kalnins, ‘Biting off More than they can Chew: Unfulfilled Development Commitments in International Master Franchising Ventures’ (2005) 5(12) Cornell Hospitality Report, 6-14.

  • Robert D Winsor, Chris Manolis, Patrick J Kaufmann and Vishal Kashyap, Manifest Conflict In Franchise Systems and The Impact Of Residual Conflict, (Presented at the 25th Annual International Society of Franchising Conference Boston University, Boston, Massachusetts, U.S.A. June 16-18, 2011)

  • Taylor Wessing, ‘FRENCH REFORM OF CONTRACT LAW: A first analysis of the impact of the reform on franchise and distribution networks’, February 2016.

Non-open access resources

PLEASE NOTE: The following resources are paid resources and are completely optional. They are not required for completion of this course. These are available on payment of the fee, buying the publication, or via subscription.

  • Gillian K Hadfield, ‘Problematic Relations: Franchising and the Law of Incomplete Contracts’ Stanford Law Review (1990) 42(4) 927.

  • Julia A Martin, ‘Arbitrating in the Alps Rather Than Litigating in Los Angeles: The Advantages of International Intellectual Property-Specific Alternative Dispute Resolution’ (1997) 49(4) Stanford Law Review 917.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Learning outcomes for this week
week_heading: Week 6: Franchisor exit and the future of franchising
step_content:
[

After participating in this week’s learning activities, you will be able to:

  • Identify a range of franchisor exit strategies.
  • Identify the most appropriate exit strategy depending on the franchisor’s circumstances.
  • Recognise future challenges for the franchise model
  • Explore emerging new applications of the franchise model

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Example(s) of social franchising
week_heading: Week 6: Franchisor exit and the future of franchising
step_content:
[

Social franchising, the application of the franchise business model to achieve socially beneficial ends rather than profit motives, is an increasingly popular method of doing business.

Discussion

What example(s) of social franchising are you aware of?

step_content:

This is a list for optional resources for Week 6.

Open access resources

  • Jenny Buchan, Lorelle Frazer, Charles Zhen Qu and Rob Nicholls, Franchisor Insolvency in Australia: Profiles, Factors, and Impacts, Journal of Marketing Channels, (2015) 22(4).

  • Jenny Buchan, ‘Franchising: A Honey Pot in a Bear Trap’, 34 (2014) Adelaide Law Review, 283.

  • Robert W. Emerson and Uri Benoliel, ‘Can Franchisee Associations Serve as a Substitute for Franchisee Protection Laws?’ (2013) 118 (1), Penn State Law Review, 99.

  • Luis Otavio Facanha, Marcelo Resende, Vicente Cardoso and Bruno H. Schroder, ‘Survival of New Firms in the Brazilian Franchising Segment: An Empirical Study’ (Working Paper Series No. 3388), CESifo, March 24, 2011.

  • Rozenn Perrigot, Manish Kacker, Guy Basset and Gérard Cliquet, ‘Antecedents of Early Adoption and Use of Social Media Networks for Stakeholder Communications: Evidence from Franchising’, Journal of Small Business Management (special issue on Franchising).

  • Kendal H. Tyre, Keri A. McWilliams and Courtney L Lindsay, II. (2013, November). ‘Entrepreneurs and franchisors tackle issues of the developing world while turning a profit’ Africa Alert. Nixon Peabody, LLP.

Cases

  • Atlanta Bread Company International, Inc. v. Lupton-Smith Et Al.

  • Dymock’s Holdings Pty Ltd And Others v Top Ryde Booksellers Pty Ltd

Non-open access resources

PLEASE NOTE: The following resource is a paid resource and is completely optional. It is not required for completion of this course. It is available on payment of the fee, buying the publication, or via subscription.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Conclusion
week_heading: Week 6: Franchisor exit and the future of franchising
step_content:
[

We hope that throughout this course, you have been able to expand your understanding of International Franchise Law and that you will be able to draw on this body of knowledge.

One of our main intents for the course was to build a community that goes beyond the traditional lawyer or franchisor communities, where experience and knowledge about this area can be shared.

We enjoyed putting this course together and have learnt so much too! We would love to hear what you thought about this course – both good and bad! Your feedback will help us improve the course in the future, and we value your opinions. Please take a few minutes to complete the post-course survey.

We would like to thank all the people without whom this course would not have been possible. Especially, a big thank you to our guest experts who enthusiastically contributed their valuable expertise for us. You can download our Credits list and more Information about guest experts below.

If you have participated and completed at least 50% of the steps in this course, you are eligible to purchase a Statement of Participation.

Finally, we would like to thank all of you for participating and sharing the journey.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]
